character.name: Carmen

appearance.skin: light olive skin with deep wrinkles, age spots on hands and forearms
appearance.hair: silver-white hair always pulled back in a neat bun at the nape of her neck
appearance.build: small, slightly stooped frame, thin but sturdy for her age
appearance.eyes: warm dark brown eyes behind round reading glasses with gold frames
appearance.distinguishing_features: deeply lined face with smile creases around eyes and mouth, strong weathered hands from decades of weaving and pottery, slight stoop in posture, gentle warm expression, small gold cross necklace always worn

character.occupation: Retired grandmother and artisan (traditional weaving on backstrap loom and pottery). Sells crafts at the Villa de Leyva Saturday market
character.living_situation: Colonial-style stone and whitewashed house with interior courtyard in Villa de Leyva, Boyaca, Colombia. Lives alone but grandchildren visit frequently. Cool mountain climate (2,144m elevation)
character.transportation: Walks everywhere in the small town, occasionally takes a taxi for longer trips

pets.cat_1: Canela — orange tabby female cat, 6 years old, Carmen's constant companion
pets.cat_2: Michi — gray and white tuxedo cat, 4 years old, playful and mischievous
pets.cat_3: Negrito — black cat, 8 years old, old and calm, sleeps most of the day

style.sleep: Warm flannel nightgown (cream-colored with small floral print), thick wool socks, hair still in bun covered with a light cotton sleep cap
style.daily: Traditional long cotton skirt (dark blue or brown), embroidered blouse (white with colorful Boyaca-style floral embroidery), wool cardigan (burgundy or forest green) for the cool mountain air, leather sandals or low black shoes, craft apron (dark blue denim) when working at loom or pottery wheel
style.going_out: Best embroidered blouse, clean dark skirt, black wool shawl (ruana lighter version), low-heeled black shoes, hair in neat bun with decorative comb, small gold earrings
style.accessories: Round reading glasses with gold frames (always), small gold cross necklace (always), woven bracelet made by granddaughter, leather watch (husband's — sentimental)

family.husband: Deceased — Don Eduardo, passed 8 years ago, was a schoolteacher in Villa de Leyva. His photo sits on bedroom nightstand.

children.son: Ricardo, 50, lives in Bogota, engineer, visits monthly
children.daughter: Lucia, 46, lives in Tunja (Boyaca capital), schoolteacher, visits weekly with children

grandchildren.grandchild_1: Sofia, 12, Lucia's daughter, loves learning weaving from Carmen
grandchildren.grandchild_2: Mateo, 9, Lucia's son, energetic, loves the cats
grandchildren.grandchild_3: Camila, 7, Lucia's youngest, shy, loves Carmen's stories
grandchildren.grandchild_4: Andresito, 14, Ricardo's son, visits less often, interested in pottery

notes.educational_context: This character represents an elderly Colombian artisan grandmother in a historic colonial town. Shows retired elderly life, traditional crafts (weaving, pottery), grandparent-grandchild relationships, and highland Colombian culture.
notes.cultural_context: Villa de Leyva, Boyaca department, cool Andean highland climate, colonial architecture, Catholic faith, traditional Boyaca cuisine (changua, arepa boyacense, cocido boyacense), artisan craft traditions, strong family and community values
notes.pedagogical_goal: Teach vocabulary related to elderly daily routines, traditional crafts (weaving, pottery), Colombian highland food and culture, family relationships, pets (cats), colonial architecture, and religious/cultural traditions
notes.language_notes: Some Spanish terms naturally used: abuela (grandmother), ruana (wool poncho), changua (milk and egg soup), arepa boyacense (corn and cheese flatbread), cocido boyacense (Boyaca stew), loom (telar), rosario (rosary), plaza (town square), etc.
notes.content_safety: All scenes age-appropriate for children 5-12. Bathroom scenes are modest — character shown wrapped in towel or already dressed. No nudity or suggestive content.
